item.title: Venezuela Leader Tries to Consolidate Power
item.description: President-elect Nicolás Maduro sought to strengthen his hold on Venezuela's presidency in the face of an angry opposition and deadly clashes.

item.title: Rockets Hit Eilat in Israel
item.description: Militants in the Sinai Peninsula fired at least two rockets at Israel's southern resort town of Eilat, officials said.

item.title: London Pauses to Mourn Thatcher
item.description: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's funeral brought large, mostly respectful crowds to the streets of London, amid heavy security and reminders of her polarizing place in the country's political history.

item.title: IMF Renews Call to Ease Austerity
item.description: The IMF called on countries that can afford it to slow the pace of austerity measures, seeking to keep a fragile global recovery on track.

item.title: Easing Is an Issue as G-20 Meets
item.description: Emerging-market members of the G-20 hope at this week's meeting to address an issue that's both a boon and a danger to their economies: the stimulus policies of the world's big central banks.

item.title: New Zealand Joins in Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: New Zealand legalized same-sex marriage, joining some dozen other countries in giving same-sex couples the same social status as couples of the opposite sex.

item.title: Philippine Guerrilla Chief Wounded
item.description: The Philippine army is intensifying its efforts to capture Abu Sayyaf guerrilla leader Isnilon Hapilon after a firefight earlier in this week left six guerrillas dead and Mr. Hapilon severely wounded, military leaders said.

item.title: Seoul to Buy Apache Helicopters
item.description: South Korea said on Wednesday it will spend $1.6 billion to buy attack helicopters from Boeing Co. to better cope with North Korean military threats.

item.title: Japan Prepares to Defend Policy at G-20
item.description: Japan will likely be in the spotlight at this week's G-20 meeting, as the yen's plunge has stoked international concerns and even drawn a warning from the U.S.

item.title: North Korea Rebuffs U.S. on Talks
item.description: North Korea said it won't consider rolling back its nuclear-weapons program in order to initiate dialogue with the U.S., saying it is up to the U.S. to first end its hostile stance.

item.title: 13 Injured in Bangalore Blast
item.description: A low-intensity blast in the southern Indian city of Bangalore injured at least 13 people, including eight security personnel.

item.title: U.S. Urged to Hold Talks With Tehran
item.description: The U.S. should change its approach on Iran by holding two-way talks and offering to ease punitive sanctions in exchange for nuclear concessions, according to a bipartisan group.

item.title: Strong Quake Hits Southeastern Iran
item.description: A magnitude-7.5 earthquake hit southeastern Iran, near the border with Pakistan, where the emergency agency said 39 had died so far.

item.title: U.K. Unemployment Rises
item.description: Unemployment rose in the U.K. in February and Britons' earnings grew at their slowest pace on record, dealing a fresh blow to the government a day after the IMF told it to ease up on austerity.

item.title: Australia's Swan Condemns Europe
item.description: Australian Treasurer Wayne Swan blamed Europe for acting as a "handbrake" on global growth and said Asia shouldn't be relied upon to prop up the world economy.

item.title: U.S. Fears Syria Rebel Victory, for Now
item.description: An outright military victory by Syria's increasingly Islamist-dominated opposition could pose a greater danger to the U.S. and its allies than would the continuing battle there, the Obama administration has concluded.

item.title: Court Bars Musharraf Candidacy
item.description: The political ambitions of former Pakistan military ruler Pervez Musharraf collapsed when a court disqualified him from taking part in coming national elections.

item.title: Italy to Elect President
item.description: Italian politicians shift from trying to form a government to another vote—the selection of a new head of state—which in turn may determine whether the country ends up going back to the polls.

item.title: Asian Counterfeit Trade Grows
item.description: Counterfeit goods, mainly from China, have become as profitable for Asia's criminal gangs as illegal drug trafficking, a U.N. report says.

item.title: Russia Clampdown on Activists Hits Courts
item.description: Russia's most prominent opposition leader is facing a trial that could end with his incarceration or at least prevent the vocal critic of President Putin from running for office.

item.title: Europe Finds 4.4% of 'Beef' Really Horse
item.description: Europe-wide tests of beef products conducted after the region's horse-meat scandal found that nearly 5% were contaminated with horse meat, and the percentage was sharply higher in a few countries, especially France and Greece.

item.title: Morocco Cancels Annual War Games With U.S.
item.description: Morocco has canceled its annual military exercises with the U.S. after the Obama administration supported adding human rights monitoring to the U.N. mission to the disputed Western Sahara territory, U.S. officials said.

item.title: $2.35 Billion Impound From Nomura
item.description: Italian financial police have impounded $2.35 billion from Banca Nomura International, a unit of Nomura Holdings, as part of an investigation into Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, prosecutors said.

item.title: Railway Spending Up in China
item.description: China spent $8.8 billion on railway infrastructure construction in the first quarter, up 28% from a year earlier.

item.title: Turkish General Charged in Plot to Kill Ex-President
item.description: Prosecutors in Turkey have charged a retired military officer with a role in a plot to kill former President Turgut Ozal, 20 years after the leader's death in disputed circumstances.

item.title: Greeks See Ray of Hope in Tourist Bookings
item.description: Greece's tourism industry is counting on a million more visitors this year, something that would provide a welcome boost to the economy.

item.title: Merkel Rivals Struggle to Find Foothold
item.description: Angela Merkel's opponents have been trying to knock her from power in September's election. With the vote five months away, the opposition is in a quandary.

item.title: A Trudeau Follows in Pierre's Dance Steps
item.description: Justin Trudeau, the 41-year-old son of legendary Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau has captured attention in a flashy campaign to win leadership of the opposition Liberal party.

item.title: Hocus-Pocus 101: Course Casts Its Spell Over Elite Students
item.description: Youngsters enter the Academy of Magical Arts, and presto change-o, come out wizzes.

item.title: Kerry Focuses on Iran, N. Korea Leaders
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Kerry, in his push to stabilize North Asia and the Middle East, is wrestling to understand the strategic calculations of two obscure and autocratic men.

item.title: Photos of the Day: April 16
item.description: In today's pictures, a family dresses up in Spain, food is left sitting at a cafe a day after bomb blasts in Boston, fans seek Rafael Nadal's autograph in Monaco, and more.

item.title: Pulitzer-Winning Breaking-News Photography
item.description: A set of photos by Rodrigo Abd, Manu Brabo, Narciso Contreras, Khalil Hamra and Muhammed Muheisen, all of the Associated Press, won the Pulitzer Prize for breaking-news photography.

item.title: Lamborghinis and Camels, on Patrol
item.description: Police officers in the emirate of Dubai recently began patrolling in a Lamborghini Aventador. But they aren't the first police officers to hop a cool ride.
